binary¶

binary.py Tools for interacting with binary recording files (C) 2014 Benjamin Naecker

binary.readbin(fname, chanlist=None)[source]¶

Read a binary recording file

binary.readbinhdr(fname)[source]¶

Read the header from a binary recording file

filtertools¶

nonlinearities¶

nonlinearities.py

Tools for fitting nonlinear functions to data

  1. 2014 bnaecker, nirum
nonlinearities.dprime(p0, p1)[source]¶

compute d’ between two distributions given mean / standard deviation

nonlinearities.estdprime(u, r, numbins=100)[source]¶

Fit a nonlinearity given a 1D stimulus projection u and spiking response r

nonlinearities.estnln(u, r, numbins=50)[source]¶

Fit a nonlinearity given a 1D stimulus projection u and spiking response r

nonlinearities.fitgaussian(xpts, ypts, p0=None)[source]¶

Fit a gaussian function to noisy data

nonlinearities.fitsigmoid(xpts, ypts)[source]¶

Fit a sigmoidal function to noisy data

nonlinearities.gaussian(x, mu, sigma)[source]¶

A 1D (unnormalized) gaussian function

nonlinearities.sigmoid(x, threshold, slope, peak, offset)[source]¶

A sigmoidal nonlinearity

setup¶

spiketools¶

spiketools.py

Tools for basic manipulation of spike trains

  1. 2014 bnaecker, nirum
spiketools.binspikes(spk, tmax=None, binsize=0.01, time=None, numTrials=1)[source]¶

Bin spike times at the given resolution. The function has two forms.

spiketools.detectevents(spk, threshold=(0.3, 0.05))[source]¶

Detects spiking events given a PSTH and spike times for multiple trials Usage: events = detectevents(spikes, threshold=(0.1, 0.005))

spiketools.estfr(tax, bspk, sigma=0.01)[source]¶

Estimate the instantaneous firing rates from binned spike counts.

class spiketools.spikingevent(startTime, stopTime, spikes)[source]¶

The spiking event class bundles together functions that are used to analyze individual firing events, consisting of spiking activity recorded across trials / cells / conditions.

Methods

eventStats()[source]¶

Compute statistics (mean and standard deviation) across trial spike counts

Usage: mu, sigma = spkevent.trialStats()

jitter()[source]¶

Computes the jitter (standard deviation) in the time to first spike across trials

Usage: sigma = spkevent.jitter()

plot(sort=False, ax=None, color='SlateGray')[source]¶

Plots this event, as a spike raster

Usage: spkevent.plot()

sort()[source]¶

Sort trial indices by the time to first spike

Usage: sortedspikes = spkevent.sort()

trialCounts()[source]¶

Count the number of spikes per trial

Usage: counts = spkevent.trialCounts()

ttfs()[source]¶

Computes the time to first spike for each trial, ignoring trials that had zero spikes

Usage: times = spkevent.ttfs()

stimulustools¶

stimulustools.py

Tools for basic manipulation of stimulus arrays.

  1. 2014 bnaecker, nirum
stimulustools.downsamplestim(stim, downfact, time=None)[source]¶

Downsample the given stimulus by the given factor.

stimulustools.getcov(stim, history, tproj=None, verbose=False)[source]¶

Computes a stimulus covariance matrix ** Warning: this is computationally expensive for large stimuli **

stimulustools.slicestim(stim, history, locations=None, tproj=None)[source]¶

Slices a spatiotemporal stimulus array (over time) into overlapping frames.

stimulustools.upsamplestim(stim, upfact, time=None)[source]¶

Upsample the given stimulus by the given factor.

visualizations¶

visualizations.py

Tools for visualizing data from retinal experiments.

  1. 2014 bnaecker, nirum
visualizations.ellipse(ell, ax=None)[source]¶

Plot the given ellipse, fit to the spatial receptive field of a cell

visualizations.playrates(rates, patches, palette='gray', numLevels=255, time=None, repeat=True, frametime=100)[source]¶

Plays a movie of the firing rate for N cells by updating the given patches (matplotlib handles) (useful in conjunction with the output of plotcells)

visualizations.playsta(sta, repeat=True, frametime=100)[source]¶

Plays a spatiotemporal spike-triggered average as a movie

visualizations.plotcells(cells, ax=None, boxdims=None, start=None, scale=0.25)[source]¶

Plot the receptive fields

visualizations.plotsta(time, sta, timeSlice=None)[source]¶

Plot a spatial and temporal filter

visualizations.plotsta1D(sta, ax=None)[source]¶

Plot a 1D spatiotemporal filter (e.g. from a bars experiment)

visualizations.psth(spikes, triallength=None, binsize=0.01, fig=None)[source]¶

Plot a PSTH from the given spike times.

visualizations.raster(spikes, triallength=None, fig=None)[source]¶

Plot a raster of spike times. The triallength keyword specifies the length of time for each trial, and the spikes array is split up into segments of that length. These groups are then plotted on top of one another, as if they are individual trials.

visualizations.rasterandpsth(spikes, triallength=None, binsize=0.01, fig=None)[source]¶

Plot a spike raster and a PSTH on the same set of axes.

visualizations.spatial(spatialFrame, ax=None, clim=None)[source]¶

Plot a spatial filter on a given axes

visualizations.temporal(time, temporalFilter, ax=None)[source]¶

Plot a temporal filter on a given axes
